witness.expan: Bibliothèque nationale de France, MS Indien 239
Tivākaram critical edition, first version, variant reading

lg.l: Well-being, protection, delight, the night,This seems to reflect the possibility that ēmam is a variant spelling for yāmam. wealth,The semantic field for Sanskrit kṣema suggests that poṉ means wealth here, rather than the more literal gold. However, it may also reflect the possibility of ēmam being derived from Sanskrit hēman.
are the extent of viḻumam, the high ones say.
Unti occurs as the navel, the wheel of a chariot, or a river;
nor do they exclude [as its meaning] a part of a yāḻ.
A drop — of water or otherwise, a remedy — or something
that removes pain and gives pleasure,
liquid they use to wash a stain out of clothes,
a ferment to curdle milk, a caustic agent, a drip,
or [used as] a particleUṟai does not appear in the Tolkāppiyam Iṭaiyiyal or it's commentaries as a particle. ― these are suitable for expressing uṟai.
A village, strength, an abode, a couch ―
Vemmai, they say, is desire and haste.
ploughing, water spinach (i.e. a shrub growing in water),
a song, a colour, having a red colour,

standOff.note: Although traditionally these two lines should be split miravupo / ṉēmāppu, all manuscripts consulted split the lines as miravupoṉ / ēmāppu.
The reading ṉantal at the beginning of the next verse in suggests that eṉpa here may have been read as eṉpaṉ.

The critical edition reads uḻavunīril together, understanding something like in ploughing water. This perhaps works better with the variant reading uḻavunilattil, in ploughed land. However, as one variant reading at the end of line 2 shows (eṉa vaintun), the first two lines have been interpreted as containing 5 items. Moreover, toyyal is given as a synonym for uḻavu in Cūṭāmaṇi 5.61. The variant reading of toyyal for toyyil is not recorded in the critical edition, but it is found in .

The 2004 Cānti Cātaṉa edition identifies this headword as irākam (11.247), although that variant is not reported in the critical edition. Another possibility is āram (), since both toyyil and āram are words for sandal paste.

entry.form: maruntu mutal nōy nīkki yiṉpam koṭukkum poruḷ-um
entry.def: remedy, etc. to remove pain and give pleasure
entry.form: maruntu mutal nōy nīkki iṉpam koṭukkum poruḷ

entry.def: fluid for removing stains from clothes
